Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Quadrupole Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer for Proteomics and Metabolomics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks to acquire a state-of-the-art mass spectrometry (MS) system for a range of metabolomics and proteomics applications. Mass spectrometry has emerged as the technology of choice for workflows seeking to identify, detect, and/or quantify metabolites and
other small molecules as well as proteins and peptides in complex biological samples. The instrument specific benefits include: very fast full-scan acquisition speed, large dynamic range, high resolution,superior sensitivity, and mass accuracy. The proposed QTOF system will support a diverse range of research projects for the PIs as well as a number of major users and collaborators: (1) identifying immunomodulatory microbiota metabolites; (2) in vitro disease model; (3) cardiac tissue engineering and regenerative medicine; (4) lipidoids for nucleic acid delivery; (5)biosynthesis of advanced biofuels; (6) non-invasive monitoring of tissue metabolism;and (7)tendon development and regeneration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were two-fold: 1) to acquire a state-of-the-art multi-user instrument for measuring both small (e.g., metabolite) and large (e.g., protein) biological molecules, and 2) to provide training for students in cutting-edge measurement methods that use this instrument as well as related data analysis techniques. Both of these goals were successfully met.

 

Over the course of the three-year project, the mass spectrometry instrument acquired through this NSF award has supported more than a dozen research projects. The research projects supported by the instrument were diverse, ranging from studies on: the physiological functions of the gut microbiome to engineered tissues to novel stimulators of stem cell differentiation to discovery of biomarkers for various diseases to investigation of basic cell signaling mechanisms in cancer. These projects include studies conducted not only by the research team that submitted the proposal, but also other user within and outside the research team’s institution. As such, the instrument acquired through this NSF award upgraded the local research infrastructure.  Importantly, the new measurement capabilities enabled by the instrument led to entirely new collaborations. A notable example is a new collaboration with Biogen, a major biopharmaceutical company located in Cambridge, MA, to identify growth inhibitory metabolites generated over the course of fed-batch process. To date, key scientific findings from data obtained using the instrument have been published in six peer-reviewed publications. At least four additional journal papers are under preparation.  

 

In addition to scientific findings, the instrument enabled methodological advances that allow the user to detect, quantify, and interpret a very large number of metabolites in complex biological samples. Motivated by the need to process and analyze very large amounts of mass spectrometry data, new collaborations were formed with computer scientists to develop open source software tools for annotating and visualizing mass spectrometry data. Developing these new methods and software tools also served as a vehicle to train undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows in advanced computational methods for data processing and annotation. To date, the project has supported the training of 24 graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdocs, from 9 different laboratories. These training efforts led to collaborations with data scientists, which formed the seed for a successful undergraduate research (REU Site) program proposal to NSF on systems biology. Through continued support by the users, the principal investigator’s department and school, the instrument facility remains in good operating condition and heavily utilized.
